messageBody:
On 1/10/2002 at 10:12 AM Ives Aerts wrote:
I've recently started to use JUnit on an embedded project and I ran
into a problem with test data.

Our product has a small internal filesystem on flash ram. So far, the
most convenient way to include test data with JUnit tests was to add
them to the test jar file and use java.lang.Class.getResource().

The problem now is that we need to test a set of classes that operate
on directory trees instead of files. So we need the likes of
java.io.File.getParent() and java.io.File.list(). AFAIK, that doesn't
work with the advised approach of using getResource().
One technique I have used is to have a method called "getUnitTestRoot" which answers a File object representing the folder where the tests should look for files. The path for this root folder is specified when the tests are run through a JVM environment property. You will eventually push this method up to the superclass of all your unit tests.
 
PROS: Every test can call new File(getUnitTestRoot(), "relative/path/name") to get a File object for the desired file within the correct folder. Tests can be located anywhere on the disk which is convenient if the tests run on multiple machines.
 
CONS: You need to remember to pass in the property each time you run the tests. Getting the path wrong can be annoying with tests failing left and right. You generally end up suclassing TestCase and making that subclass the parent class of all your tests, which you may find ugly.
